column4: The only possible clue I've uncovered is that if I invoke /usr/bin/hgtk from the command line I get the message "abort: This version of TortoiseHg requires Mercurial version 1.5.n to 1.6.n, but finds 1.4.3" which makes no sense since that executable is installed by the tortoisehg package which lists "mercurial (>= 1.4)" as its dependency.
...also it seemed to be working fine two weeks ago.
It may also be worth mentioning that the hg command line tools still work fine.
launch nautilus from a terminal and watch for error messages
Yeah, I tried that but I got nothing.
I actually got a message showing the nautilus job as having finished, so I wonder if it doesn't do a fork of some kind and let the parent process terminate.

Ah, the trick it to look in .xsession-errors.  And it's showing the same thing I mentioned before (because I think that just calls hgtk), namely, "abort: This version of TortoiseHg requires Mercurial version 1.5.n to 1.6.n, but finds 1.4.3".
Maybe the tortoisehg package was updated some time recently and the dependencies are screwed up.
apt-cache show mercurial

I'm not sure what you're thinking I ought to be looking for.  As I said, I have version 1.4.3 (1.4.3-1, actually).  I don't know if there's a way to see when that package version was added to the repo.
Were you thinking there was something useful to be gleaned from the output of 'apt-cache show mercurial' ?
launchpad
Yes.  I'll try that once it starts working again.  At the moment it seems to be having difficulties.
save yourself the pain and do a clean install, ubuntu desktop upgrades are still .. not very well tested
I may go that way eventually, but given that it seems superficially to work 99% of the way and it took me a while to download the 2.5 GB of packages, I think I won't give up quite that easily.
all the best

It's funny.  I've been running Ubuntu since warty and for a long time version upgrades went quite smoothly.  One of the things I liked about Ubuntu is that it "just worked".  But recently my experience has been much more buggy (which goes for Ubuntu overall, actually).
it's a consequence of system complexity growing with new "cooler" features
I guess that's probably so.  For my part I'd take reliability over cool, but I recognize that's a subjective value judgment. :-)
desktop-wise, i dont see how my any distro out there now is better than  the last install of  mandrake linux  i had in 2004!  it's another story on the server-side though.
Assuming more googling doesn't yield an answer, do you think I should take my issue to ubuntuforums or file a bug on launchpad?
perhaps the forums would help, i dont think filing a bug would really help even though you should
I suppose nothing stops me from doing both.
